metadata.titleEn: Aerosol optical property dataset of the Tibetan Plateau by ground-based observation (2009-2016)
metadata.description: The measurement data of the sun spectrophotometer can be directly used to perform inversion on the optical thickness of the non-water vapor channel, Rayleigh scattering, aerosol optical thickness, and moisture content of the atmospheric air column (using the measurement data at 936 nm of the water vapor channel). The aerosol optical property data set of the Tibetan Plateau by ground-based observations was obtained by adopting the Cimel 318 sun photometer, and both the Mt. Qomolangma and Namco stations were involved. The temporal coverage of the data is from 2009 to 2016, and the temporal resolution is one day. The sun photometer has eight observation channels from visible light to near infrared. The center wavelengths are 340, 380, 440, 500, 670, 870, 940 and 1120 nm. The field angle of the instrument is 1.2°, and the sun tracking accuracy is 0.1°. According to the direct solar radiation, the aerosol optical thickness of 6 bands can be obtained, and the estimated accuracy is 0.01 to 0.02. Finally, the AERONET unified inversion algorithm was used to obtain aerosol optical thickness, Angstrom index, particle size spectrum, single scattering albedo, phase function, birefringence index, asymmetry factor, etc.
metadata.instructions: File name: the data is stored in Excel format, and the file name is named after the time + place, such as "090101_ Nam_CO", which represents the aerosol optical characteristics in Namuco area from January 1, 2009 to December 31, 2016

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) is one of the most imposing topographic features on the surface of the Earth. With an immense area (about 2,500,000 km2) and mean elevation of more than 4000 m above sea level, TP plays a key role in Asia climatology and atmospheric circulation. Meanwhile, the atmosphere over the plateau is probably the least affected by human activities in the Asian continent due to the sparse population and minimal industries, providing a unique opportunity to describe atmospheric processes and changes. In this context, several model simulation and satellite observation works have been carried out over the TP to elucidate the effects of aerosol on regional climate and water cycles. Considering its huge area and essential role in the climate system, the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over TP leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments. AERONET (Aerosol Robotic Network) is a worldwide aerosol characterization network with the automatic CIMEL Sun/sky radiometer as the principal instrument. Due to its significant advances on observation techniques and analysis methods, AERONET has been producing reliably and continuously detailed optical properties of various types of aerosols worldwide.
research objective: This paper will focus on the optical properties (AOD, Angstrom parameter) and volume size distribution of aerosols in this poorly understood region based on the first-year (Aug 2006–Jul 2007) AERONET data. We expect such information can help to understand the atmosphere condition and interactive processes over the TP, validate the product of satellite measurements, and improve the initialization for climate models involving TP and the surrounding regions.
challenges: Considering its huge area and essential role in the climate system, the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over TP leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments.
methods: Measurements of aerosol optical properties were made with AERONET sun/sky radiometers at the Nam Co Station, a remote high elevation site in central TP from August 2006 to July 2007. In order to determine the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types, twelve TSP samples (monthly) were also analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, PHILIPS XL 30 FEG) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX).
dataset: Very low aerosol optical values were observed with annual mean Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) of 0.05 at 500 nm during August 2006 to July 2007. Angstrom parameters were also low with an average of 0.42±0.27. In August 2006, an automatic sun and sky scanning radiometer (CIMEL) was established at Nam Co, central Tibetan Plateau as an AERONET site.
findings: It was also found the AOD produced by AREONET measurement in this study (annual mean value 0.05) is significantly lower than simultaneous MODIS observation. The WVC has a clear seasonal pattern with maximum values in summer and minimum values during autumn and winter, which is consistent with the meteorological record by AWS and reflects the reliability of the WVC retrieval method. The volume size distribution of aerosols is bimodal except for spring. This work could enhance our knowledge on the aerosol distribution over the TP and helpful for the modeling of climate change and validation of satellite remote sensing products.

Definition.Question: What are the primary data collection techniques used for observing aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The primary data collection technique involves the use of Cimel 318 sun photometers, which measure direct solar radiation across eight spectral channels to derive aerosol optical thickness and other properties. Observations are made daily, and the AERONET unified inversion algorithm is used to analyze the data.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting aerosol optical data in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include the vast area and high elevation of the Tibetan Plateau, which can introduce uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments due to limited knowledge of aerosol optical properties. The region's sparse population and minimal industrial activities also mean fewer opportunities for data collection compared to more populated areas.

Definition.Question: What potential datasets could be used to study the optical properties of aerosols in high-altitude regions?
Definition.Answer: Potential datasets include those collected by AERONET using automatic sun/sky radiometers, which provide detailed optical properties of aerosols. These datasets are valuable for understanding atmospheric conditions, validating satellite measurements, and improving climate model initialization.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using the CIMEL sun/sky radiometer compare to those utilizing scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) in capturing aerosol optical properties?
Comparison.Answer: The CIMEL sun/sky radiometer continuously observes aerosol optical properties such as optical depth and Angstrom parameter, providing detailed optical properties through AERONET's unified inversion algorithm. In contrast, SEM and EDX analyze TSP samples to determine aerosol types on a monthly basis, offering insights into the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges in detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau imply uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments?
Interpretation.Answer: The lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments, as this region plays a key role in Asia's climatology and atmospheric circulation.

Interpretation.Question: What interpretation can be made about the reliability of aerosol optical depth measurements when comparing AERONET and satellite observations in the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The AERONET measurement of aerosol optical depth showed significantly lower values than simultaneous MODIS satellite observations, indicating potential discrepancies between ground-based and satellite data, which could affect the validation and interpretation of remote sensing products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau, and how does this affect climate modeling and assessments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau is primarily due to its vast area and essential role in the climate system, leading to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the differences in aerosol optical depth values observed from ground-based measurements and satellite observations over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The differences in aerosol optical depth values observed from ground-based measurements and satellite observations over the Tibetan Plateau may be caused by the unique atmospheric conditions of the region and the limitations in satellite retrieval methods, as seen in the significantly lower AOD values from AERONET compared to MODIS observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the Tibetan Plateau considered a unique region for studying atmospheric processes and changes, and what are the implications for data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau is considered a unique region for studying atmospheric processes and changes due to its sparse population and minimal industrial activity, which minimizes human impact, providing a unique opportunity to describe natural atmospheric processes and changes. This uniqueness necessitates specialized data collection methods that can capture the undisturbed atmospheric conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using Cimel 318 sun photometers for continuous data collection on the accuracy and reliability of aerosol optical property datasets in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Cimel 318 sun photometers allows for high-precision measurement of aerosol optical properties with a sun tracking precision of 0.1° and an estimated accuracy of 0.01-0.02 for aerosol optical thickness. This leads to highly reliable datasets that can reduce uncertainties in climate models, especially in remote regions such as the Tibetan Plateau, where human activities minimally impact the atmosphere.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties affect climate modeling and assessments in regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments. This is due to the essential role that aerosols play in the climate system, affecting regional climate and water cycles. More precise data collection and analysis, like those provided by AERONET, are crucial for improving these models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of using Cimel 318 sun photometers for collecting aerosol optical properties on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to capture continuous and reliable data on aerosol optical properties such as aerosol optical depth (AOD), Angstrom index, and other related parameters, which help in understanding atmospheric processes and changes over the Tibetan Plateau. This information is crucial for improving climate models and validating satellite observations in this region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze aerosol types using a combination of AERONET data and scanning electron microscopy in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing aerosol types using both AERONET data and scanning electron microscopy allows for a comprehensive understanding of aerosol characteristics and their distribution in the Tibetan Plateau. This approach helps in identifying different aerosol types and enhances the reliability of data used for climate modeling and assessment.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of investigating aerosol volume size distribution and optical properties using AERONET on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include understanding the atmospheric conditions and interactive processes over the Tibetan Plateau, validating satellite measurement products, and improving the initialization for climate models. This data provides insights into aerosol distribution patterns, which are essential for addressing uncertainties in climate modeling over this significant geographic area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in utilizing a sun/sky radiometer to obtain aerosol optical properties at high-altitude sites?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Measurements of aerosol optical properties are made with AERONET sun/sky radiometers. This involves establishing an automatic sun and sky scanning radiometer, such as the CIMEL, at a site like Nam Co in the central Tibetan Plateau. The radiometer captures data that are processed using the AERONET unified inversion algorithm to obtain parameters such as aerosol optical thickness, Angstrom index, and volume size distribution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are aerosol samples collected and analyzed to determine their types and properties in remote locations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Aerosol samples are collected monthly, with twelve TSP (Total Suspended Particles) samples analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX). This method allows for the determination of the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types at remote high elevation sites like the Nam Co Station in the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate measurement of aerosol optical properties in remote high-elevation sites like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of AERONET sun/sky radiometers, such as the CIMEL Sun/sky radiometer, enables reliable and continuous measurement of detailed aerosol optical properties, even in remote high-elevation sites like the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods enable the differentiation of aerosol types in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Enablement.Answer: The combination of AERONET measurements with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) enables the determination of different aerosol types by analyzing collected total suspended particle (TSP) samples.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of continuous ground-based observation datasets enable improved climate modeling and satellite measurement validation over the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Continuous ground-based observations, such as those obtained using Cimel 318 sun photometers, provide detailed aerosol optical properties, which help to validate satellite measurements and improve the initialization of climate models involving the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding regions.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in accurately modeling the climate system over the Tibetan Plateau without detailed aerosol optical properties?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments, as the plateau plays a key role in regional climate systems and atmospheric circulation.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using CIMEL sun/sky radiometers for capturing aerosol optical properties on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of CIMEL sun/sky radiometers is considered effective for capturing detailed optical properties of aerosols on the Tibetan Plateau due to its ability to provide reliably and continuously detailed data, as evidenced by its successful deployment at the Nam Co Station. Additionally, the AERONET network's standardized algorithms enhance the accuracy of the data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how might the integration of scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis enhance the understanding of aerosol types in this region?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis can enhance the understanding of aerosol types by providing detailed compositional analysis, which complements optical measurements and helps in identifying the occurrence and percentages of different aerosol types, thereby refining climate models and satellite product validation.

Assertion.Answer: Considering its huge area and essential role in the climate system, the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over TP leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments.
